240.title: Adventure Story Comic Books, Strips, Etc.
notes:
The "genre" called "adventure story" does not admit of a tidy definition. In one sense the term is a way to group the various non-domestic genres as listed here below, which can then be thought of as "sub-genres" of adventure story comics. When an anthology style comic book includes more than two of these subgenres it is usually assigned the label "adventure story" in this index.

There is a more specific kind of adventure story, as familiar to fiction readers in the works of such authors as H. Rider Haggard, Emilio Salgari, or Karl May, to name a few. In comics these are perhaps best embodied in the adventures of Tintin, Uncle Scrooge, and Indiana Jones, in which an adventurer, an "explorer," from the developed world travels to an exotic location in search of something of value. This thing of value could be a feature story (as with the nominally journalistic Tintin), a negotiable treasure (as with the acquisitive McDuck), or some mystical truth (or whatever you prefer to think motivates Mr. Jones). What these stories have in common is a protagonist empowered by "civilization," an exotic location (i.e., they take place in colonial territories) and extractive intent. Explicit colonialism and latter-day economic imperialism are the heart of this part of the adventure story genre. This kind of story could be a genre of its own if it were to be named separately.

A third strain of adventure stories is a sort of "other" genre, the kind of story that involves adventurous behavior but without the trappings of the named genres. Little Orphan Annie and Annie Rooney travel a realistic, unexotic world and attract adventure to themselves, for example. Kinds of stories that have not yet achieved full "generic" status in this index are thus included, such as "action journalism" stories, pirate stories, and other sea stories. Also, in this index titles that proclaim "adventure" will usually locate here, as with Amazing High Adventure or Bold Adventure. Finally, this list, as you will find by scrolling down for the next several thousand lines, includes titles whose presence is not readily explained. The process of developing and focusing this terminology will continue.
